building-capability-for-all.description: Effectiveness in this area is having a strong focus on continuous learning for oneself, others and the organisation. For all staff, it's being open to learning, about keeping one's own knowledge and skill set current and evolving. At senior levels, it's about talent management and ensuring a diverse blend of capability and skills is identified and developed to meet current and future business needs. It's also about creating a learning and knowledge culture across the organisation to inform future plans and transformational change.

level1.effective: Identify own skills, knowledge and behaviour gaps to inform own development plan and discuss these with the line manager
level1.ineffective: Take a passive approach to personal development, mostly relying on others to identify learning points or dismissing constructive feedback

level1.effective: Recognise and take time to achieve own learning and development objectives
level1.ineffective: Lack interest in personal development, decline all opportunities to learn e.g. through attending programmes or engaging in work-place learning

level1.effective: Find ways to learn and personally improve in the completion of day-to-day tasks
level1.ineffective: Maintain a rigid view of daily tasks, missing opportunities to learn or to improve how they do things

level1.effective: Improve own performance by taking on board feedback from colleagues from different backgrounds
level1.ineffective: Ignore or undervalue the contributions and views of others from different backgrounds

level1.effective: Share learning with team and colleagues; contribute to the team's shared learning and understanding
level1.ineffective: Keep knowledge and expertise to themselves rather than share for the benefit of the whole team

level1.effective: React constructively to developmental feedback and make changes as a result
level1.ineffective: Do little to follow through on constructive developmental feedback, ignore or dismiss its value

level2.effective: Take ownership of team and individual development by identifying capability needs and consistently achieving development objectives
level2.ineffective: Fail to address own capability needs or identify learning opportunities

level2.effective: Take responsibility for the quality of own work and seeking opportunities for improvement through continuous learning
level2.ineffective: Resist opportunities to broaden work responsibilities

level2.effective: Proactively support the development plans of others
level2.ineffective: Resist learning and development requests from others

level2.effective: Take account of the diverse contributions of team members and delegate work to improve capabilities of all
level2.ineffective: Tend to keep work to themselves that could be a helpful development opportunity for a team member, failing to ensure equality of opportunity

level2.effective: Encourage and be open to developmental feedback from others
level2.ineffective: Be disinterested in giving or receiving constructive feedback

level3.effective: Identify and address team or individual capability requirements and gaps to deliver current and future work
level3.ineffective: Manage others in a weak or ineffective manner, allowing capability gaps to persist

level3.effective: Identify and develop all talented team members to support succession planning, devoting time to coach, mentor and develop others
level3.ineffective: Choose to only develop team members who reflect own capabilities, styles and strengths

level3.effective: Value and respond to different personal needs in the team using these to develop others and promote inclusiveness
level3.ineffective: Be insensitive to and unaware of the diverse aspirations and capability of all members of the team

level3.effective: Proactively manage own career and identify own learning needs with line manager, plan and carry out work-place learning opportunities
level3.ineffective: Passively expect others to identify and manage their learning needs

level3.effective: Continually seek and act on feedback to evaluate and improve their own and team's performance
level3.ineffective: Make no attempt to learn from or apply lessons of feedback

level4.effective: Ensure that individual and organisational learning and talent development opportunities are fully exploited in order to enhance organisational capability
level4.ineffective: Ignore emerging learning and development opportunities and the sharing of that learning to benefit the organisation

level4.effective: Role model work-place based learning and encourage development, talent and career management for all staff
level4.ineffective: Not follow up on learning to ensure colleagues practise and apply new learning to the benefit of the organisation

level4.effective: Coach and support colleagues to take responsibility for their own development (through giving accountability, varied assignments and on-going feedback)
level4.ineffective: Make token efforts to coach and develop people, allow staff to de-prioritise own development

level4.effective: Establish and drive intra and inter team discussions to learn from experience and adapt organisational processes and plans
level4.ineffective: Stay ignorant of the experience of colleagues and take little notice of the potential learning available

level4.effective: Identify capability requirements needed to deliver future team objectives and manage team resources to meet these needs
level4.ineffective: Allow team capability needs to go unaddressed and fail to use development opportunities and effective performance management to maximise team capability

level4.effective: Prioritise and role model continuous self learning and development, including leadership, management and people skills
level4.ineffective: Place low priority on people management and development, seldom seek feedback or challenge, and prioritise professional expertise over leadership, management and people skills

level5.effective: Champion development, talent and career management for all staff and make learning a reality by encouraging and providing a range of development experiences
level5.ineffective: Allow delivery to dominate to the exclusion of learning and development activities, missing out on longer term business benefits and ignoring the organisational learning dimension

level5.effective: Create an inclusive environment, one from which all staff, including under-represented groups, can benefit
level5.ineffective: Tolerate discriminatory thinking and practices when building capability in the organisation

level5.effective: Encourage work-place based learning, ensure colleagues take responsibility for their own learning and share it to build organisational capability
level5.ineffective: Fail to ensure colleagues practise and share new learning of benefit to the business

level5.effective: Devote dedicated time to supporting and empowering people through coaching and mentoring and sharing expertise/knowledge
level5.ineffective: Focus resources on technical knowledge/ skills gaps at the expense of leadership skills or development of future talent

level5.effective: Identify capability requirements to deliver Departmental 3-5 year strategy and grow sustainable capability across all groups including those identified as having high potential
level5.ineffective: Allow ineffective performance management which fails to narrow capability gaps for the organisation or grow available talent

level5.effective: Role model continuous learning and self development, evaluating own effectiveness and growth and planning next learning steps accordingly
level5.ineffective: Seldom seek feedback and fail to seize opportunities for personal development

level6.effective: Champion the strategic importance of people, talent management and development issues, building a strong culture of continuous learning and knowledge sharing
level6.ineffective: Allow organisational learning to be lost and fail to create a climate where colleagues can apply new learning relevant to the business

level6.effective: Operate with an acute awareness of inclusiveness, equality and diversity and build capability strategies to support careers for all employees
level6.ineffective: Show little ability or commitment to enabling equal opportunities for people to realise their aspirations

level6.effective: Develop and maintain organisational commitment to problem solving, empowering people to experiment and achieve organisational results together
level6.ineffective: Allow a sense that problem solving is only for a few individuals and only at certain times

level6.effective: Be renowned as an effective coach and sounding board for senior people
level6.ineffective: Invest little personal time to develop talent and future leaders

level6.effective: Take a strategic perspective to identifying the capability needs of the Department and identifying and nurturing future leaders
level6.ineffective: Adopt a short term perspective to people and talent management issues – struggle to assess long-term and evolving people requirements for the Department

level6.effective: Role model continuous learning and self development, evaluating own effectiveness and growth and planning next learning steps accordingly
level6.ineffective: Be resistant to or dismissive of personal feedback and see personal growth as not relevant at their level

building-capability-for-all.title: Building Capability for All

collaborating-and-partnering.description: People skilled in this area create and maintain positive, professional and trusting working relationships with a wide range of people within and outside the Civil Service to help get business done. At all levels, it requires working collaboratively, sharing information and building supportive, responsive relationships with colleagues and stakeholders, whilst having the confidence to challenge assumptions. At senior levels, it's about delivering business objectives through creating an inclusive environment, encouraging collaboration and building effective partnerships including relationships with Ministers.

level1.effective: Proactively contribute to the work of the whole team
level1.ineffective: Focus on own objectives at the expense of supporting colleagues

level1.effective: Get to know fellow team members/colleagues and understand their viewpoints and preferences
level1.ineffective: Is overly critical and blaming of people who have different working styles or development needs

level1.effective: Seek help when needed in order to complete own work effectively
level1.ineffective: Miss opportunities to generate better outcomes for the customer through collaboration with others

level1.effective: Be open to taking on different roles
level1.ineffective: Assume specific, unvarying role responsibilities

level1.effective: Try to see issues from others' perspectives and check understanding
level1.ineffective: Look at issues from own viewpoint only

level1.effective: Listen to the views of others and show sensitivity towards others
level1.ineffective: Not treat all colleagues fairly, equitably or with respect

level2.effective: Demonstrate interest in others and develop a range of contacts outside own team to help get the job done
level2.ineffective: Ignore the knowledge and expertise that a wider network of colleagues and partners can bring to the work of the team

level2.effective: Change ways of working to facilitate collaboration for the benefit of the team's work
level2.ineffective: Continue to work in set ways that make it difficult for colleagues to contribute to or benefit from the team's work

level2.effective: Proactively seek information, resources and support from others outside own immediate team in order to help achieve results
level2.ineffective: Take a narrow approach to resolving resourcing issues in own area and fail to explore other resourcing opportunities and possibilities

level2.effective: Readily identify opportunities to share knowledge, information and learning and make progress by working with colleagues
level2.ineffective: Rarely share information, or restrict it to immediate colleagues only

level2.effective: Listen attentively to others and check their understanding by asking questions
level2.ineffective: Show a lack of interest or skill in interacting with others

level2.effective: Take responsibility for creating a working environment that encourages equality, diversity and inclusion
level2.ineffective: Adopt a biased, exclusive or disrespectful manner in their dealings with others

level3.effective: Establish relationships with a range of stakeholders to support delivery of business outcomes
level3.ineffective: Devote little or no time to networking or engaging with immediate stakeholders, preferring to work in isolation

level3.effective: Invest time to generate a common focus and genuine team spirit
level3.ineffective: Demonstrate limited capability to get the best from people and create barriers or negative feelings between and within teams

level3.effective: Actively seek input from a diverse range of people
level3.ineffective: Display little appreciation of the value of different contributions and perspectives

level3.effective: Readily share resources to support higher priority work, showing pragmatism and support for the shared goals of the organisation
level3.ineffective: Create reasons why resources and support cannot be shared

level3.effective: Deal with conflict in a prompt, calm and constructive manner
level3.ineffective: Show a lack of concern for others' perspectives

level3.effective: Encourage collaborative team working within own team and across the Department
level3.ineffective: Support individual or silo ways of working

level4.effective: Actively build and maintain a network of colleagues and contacts to achieve progress on objectives and shared interests
level4.ineffective: Only seek to build contacts in immediate work group, neglect to create a wider network beyond this

level4.effective: Demonstrate genuine care for staff and others – build strong interpersonal relationships
level4.ineffective: Neglect to maintain relationships during difficult times

level4.effective: Encourage contributions and involvement from a broad and diverse range of staff by being visible and accessible
level4.ineffective: Operate within a narrow frame of reference and avoid adopting a fuller perspective with associated complexity

level4.effective: Effectively manage team dynamics when working across Departmental and other boundaries
level4.ineffective: Be overly protective of own initiatives and miss opportunities to network across boundaries

level4.effective: Actively involve partners to deliver a business outcome through collaboration that achieves better results for citizens
level4.ineffective: Struggle to manage, or actively ignore other parties' agendas

level4.effective: Seek constructive outcomes in discussions, challenge assumptions but remain willing to compromise when it is beneficial to progress
level4.ineffective: Push forward initiatives on basis of personal agenda or advantage and refuse to compromise; stay wedded to one outcome

level5.effective: Proactively create, maintain and promote a strong network of connections with colleagues across the Department, wider Civil Service and externally
level5.ineffective: Focus on delivery at the expense of building networks and effective relationships across and beyond their area

level5.effective: Actively promote knowledge and resource sharing with peers and across functions
level5.ineffective: Consistently protect resources and interests of own area at the expense of Departmental priorities

level5.effective: Encourage and establish principles of working effectively across boundaries to support the business
level5.ineffective: Act selfishly to protect own area and resist involvement from external colleagues or experts

level5.effective: Encourage teams to engage with a variety of delivery partners and stakeholders and listen to their feedback
level5.ineffective: Give teams limited support about how to work collaboratively with delivery partners, discourage early engagement

level5.effective: Build high performing teams within own area, aligned around common goals
level5.ineffective: Struggle to address low morale or de-motivation within teams; create boundary or resource tensions between the teams

level5.effective: Set out clear expectations that bullying, harassment and discrimination are unacceptable
level5.ineffective: Permit unacceptable or disrespectful behaviour to persist in own area and with other teams

level6.effective: Build a strong network of collaborative relationships and partnerships across the Civil Service, at the highest levels in Government and beyond (UK, EU and globally) to help Departmental and wider Civil Service objectives
level6.ineffective: Restrict collaboration to existing relationships, give limited attention to the importance of building networks

level6.effective: Be a full partner on the Board and act for the wider good of the Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Encourage own Department to focus on its pressures and agenda at the expense of wider collaboration

level6.effective: Drive a diverse and collaborative working culture which encourages transparency and open communication
level6.ineffective: Create and allow cliques and narrow ways of working within and across functions, promoting a „knowledge is power' culture

level6.effective: Confront issues and challenge assumptions at the highest levels with delivery partners, stakeholders and clients in an assertive yet constructive way
level6.ineffective: Not involve partners and stakeholders early on in the development of policies, services and delivery options

level6.effective: Work effectively with Non Executive Directors to bring together political and official leadership to improve governance at board level
level6.ineffective: Fail to utilise the experience and input offered by Non Executive Directors

collaborating-and-partnering.title: Collaborating and Partnering

leading-and-communicating.description: At all levels, effectiveness in this area is about leading from the front and communicating with clarity, conviction and enthusiasm. It's about supporting principles of fairness of opportunity for all and a dedication to a diverse range of citizens. At senior levels, it is about establishing a strong direction and a persuasive future vision; managing and engaging with people with honesty and integrity, and upholding the reputation of the Department and the Civil Service.

level1.effective: Put forward their own views in a clear and constructive manner, choosing an appropriate communication method, e.g. email/ telephone/ face to face
level1.ineffective: Talk negatively about the organisation, their team or colleagues

level1.effective: Act in a fair and respectful way in dealing with others
level1.ineffective: Show bias or a lack of respect and treat some groups more favourably than others

level1.effective: Write clearly in plain simple language and check work for spelling and grammar, learning from previous inaccuracies
level1.ineffective: Make little effort to ensure they express themselves in an effective manner that others can easily understand

level1.effective: Ask open questions to appreciate others' point of view
level1.ineffective: Withhold work information and refuse to share knowledge that would help others do a better job

level2.effective: Display enthusiasm around goals and activities – adopting a positive approach when interacting with others
level2.ineffective: Express limited interest in goals and activities

level2.effective: Listen to, understand, respect and accept the value of different views, ideas and ways of working
level2.ineffective: Adopt a biased, exclusive or disrespectful manner in their dealings with others

level2.effective: Express ideas effectively, both orally and in writing, and with sensitivity and respect for others
level2.ineffective: Demonstrate no awareness of the impact of their behaviour on others nor consider the potential reactions of others to the ideas put forward

level2.effective: Confidently handle challenging conversations or interviews
level2.ineffective: Unable to deal objectively with conflicts and disputes when they arise

level2.effective: Confront and deal promptly with inappropriate language or behaviours, including bullying, harassment or discrimination
level2.ineffective: Avoid challenging inappropriate language or behaviours

level3.effective: Take opportunities to regularly communicate and interact with staff, helping to clarify goals and activities and the links between these and Departmental strategy
level3.ineffective: Be rarely available to staff and others, communicate infrequently

level3.effective: Recognise, respect and reward the contribution and achievements of others
level3.ineffective: Take the credit for others' achievements

level3.effective: Communicate in a succinct, engaging manner and stand ground when needed
level3.ineffective: Give in readily when challenged

level3.effective: Communicate using appropriate styles, methods and timing, including digital channels, to maximise understanding and impact
level3.ineffective: Communicate in a set way with little variation, without tailoring messages, style and timing to the needs of the target audience

level3.effective: Promote the work of the Department and play an active part in supporting the Civil Service values and culture
level3.ineffective: Be ignorant of and/or dismissive of broader organisational values and goals, such as equality and diversity

level3.effective: Convey enthusiasm and energy about their work and encourage others to do the same
level3.ineffective: Communicate information without consideration for the audience or with limited/low levels of enthusiasm and effort

level4.effective: Be visible to staff and stakeholders and regularly undertake activities to engage and build trust with people involved in area of work
level4.ineffective: Only speak to staff and stakeholders in a face-to-face environment when pressured to do so

level4.effective: Clarify strategies and plans, giving clear sense of direction and purpose for self and team
level4.ineffective: Leave team unclear about vision and goals of their immediate business area

level4.effective: Stand by, promote or defend own and team's actions and decisions where needed
level4.ineffective: Leave team members to cope alone in difficult situations – provide little support for their teams

level4.effective: Confidently engage with stakeholders and colleagues at all levels to generate commitment to goals
level4.ineffective: Miss opportunities to transform the team, wait for others to take the lead

level4.effective: Lead by example, role modelling ethics, integrity, impartiality and the elimination of bias by building diverse teams and promoting a working environment that supports the Civil Service values and code
level4.ineffective: Act in ways that are at odds with their expressed beliefs

level4.effective: Be open and inviting of the views of others and respond despite pressure to ignore, revert or concede
level4.ineffective: Set out a course of action and apply it without listening to others or adapting where relevant

level5.effective: Lead from the front, communicating and motivating people towards stretching goals
level5.ineffective: Unable to translate, articulate and inspire people around vision and goals

level5.effective: Actively promote the Department's reputation externally and internally – publicise successes widely
level5.ineffective: Avoid activities to build profile within or outside the Department

level5.effective: Inspire staff and delivery partners to engage fully with long term vision and purpose of the Department, supporting them to make sense of change
level5.ineffective: Make limited effort to create clarity for others around strategy or purpose, leave staff to work through changes on their own

level5.effective: Actively promote diversity and equality of opportunity inside and outside the Civil Service
level5.ineffective: Disregard the need to consistently promote good diversity practice

level5.effective: Communicate with conviction and clarity in the face of tough negotiations or challenges
level5.ineffective: Back down readily in the face of challenge or tough negotiations

level5.effective: Influence external partners, stakeholders and customers successfully – secure mutually beneficial outcomes
level5.ineffective: Lose focus under pressure and neglect the need to agree joint outcomes

level6.effective: Actively develop and protect the reputation of the Department and the Civil Service – create a sense of pride
level6.ineffective: Overlook opportunities to champion achievements of employees in the Department and the Civil Service

level6.effective: Shape, promote and exemplify desired Departmental and the Civil Service values and culture
level6.ineffective: Act in ways which are at odds with desired culture and values – damages the Civil Service leadership reputation internally and externally

level6.effective: Be highly articulate and credible at the most senior levels across and outside the Civil Service, consistently delivering inspiring, engaging and meaningful messages about the future direction
level6.ineffective: Lack confidence or impact at high levels, struggle with media spotlight, miss opportunities to communicate messages or give a confused or uninspiring narrative about what's important

level6.effective: Engage positively in debate and seek to resolve issues with peers across the Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Operate independently, rarely asking for input from senior colleagues and communicating infrequently

level6.effective: Demonstrate insight into the link between the moral and business case for equality and diversity and achieving organisational priorities
level6.ineffective: Disregard the link between the moral and business case for diverse and sustainable outcomes

level6.effective: Negotiate with and influence external partners, stakeholders and customers successfully at the highest levels
level6.ineffective: Lack insight into the different motivations and agendas of the variety of stakeholders

leading-and-communicating.title: Leading and Communicating

achieving-commercial-outcomes.description: Being effective in this area is about maintaining an economic, long-term focus in all activities. For all, it's about having a commercial, financial and sustainable mindset to ensure all activities and services are delivering added value and working to stimulate economic growth. At senior levels, it's about identifying economic, market and customer issues and using these to promote innovative business models, commercial partnerships and agreements to deliver greatest value; and ensuring tight commercial controls of finances, resources and contracts to meet strategic priorities.

level1.effective: Understand the relevant terms and conditions, including deliverables of relevant contracts
level1.ineffective: Demonstrate little understanding of what suppliers are obliged to deliver, how or by when

level1.effective: Be aware of and comply with Departmental procurement processes and know when to access commercial expertise
level1.ineffective: Not recognise or understand Departmental procurement procedures

level1.effective: Check suppliers and partners are providing relevant and timely data to monitor contracts
level1.ineffective: Allow inaccurate or late records

level1.effective: Learn about customers and suppliers needs
level1.ineffective: Take no steps to learn who their suppliers and customers are or to understand their interests and concerns

level2.effective: Be able to identify and access departmental procurement and commercial expertise
level2.ineffective: Make poor quality commercial decisions or take actions without having engaged with departmental commercial experts

level2.effective: Understand and be able to explain departmental approach to assigning contractual and financial delegations
level2.ineffective: Enter into commercial arrangements without having the authority to do so

level2.effective: Recognise when deliverables and/or services derived from a commercial arrangement are not being delivered to the required level of quality or standard and take appropriate action
level2.ineffective: Not raise issues when cost or outcomes drift significantly from agreements

level2.effective: Fully meet commercial confidentiality and data security requirements in contracts
level2.ineffective: Put confidentiality and other security requirements at risk

level3.effective: Consider, in consultation with commercial experts, alternative ways of working with partners and contractors to identify more efficient outcomes, balancing cost, quality and turn around times
level3.ineffective: Overlook opportunities for continuous improvement in service delivery

level3.effective: Work with commercial experts in engaging effectively and intelligently with delivery partners in order to define and/or improve service delivery
level3.ineffective: Lack impact when engaging with commercial experts and delivery partners through misunderstanding commercial issues

level3.effective: Gather and use evidence to assess the costs, benefits and risks of a wide range of delivery options when making commercial decisions
level3.ineffective: Take a narrow view of options and focus only on cost, rather than long term value and impact

level3.effective: Identify and understand relevant legal and commercial terms, concepts, policies and processes (including project approvals and assurance procedures) to deliver agreed outcomes
level3.ineffective: Show a lack of understanding about relevant commercial concepts processes and systems

level4.effective: Work effectively with different organisations such as private sector and voluntary groups (in tandem with commercial experts) to commission and source solutions to achieve policy and organisational goals
level4.ineffective: Take a narrow view on options for delivering policy and business goals

level4.effective: Understand the commercial drivers that will influence a private or third sector organisation and the levers that can be used in negotiating/influencing contractual arrangements
level4.ineffective: Show little or no understanding or appreciation of the economic or commercial drivers that will influence the behaviour of suppliers

level4.effective: Be able to recognise and understand the commercial tools such as pricing models, open book accounting, supply chain management that commercial experts can deploy to extract value from contracts
level4.ineffective: Has little or no knowledge or understanding of the commercial tools used to extract value from contracts

level4.effective: Interact confidently and effectively as an intelligent and highly credible customer with counterparts from the commercial delivery organisations and commercial experts
level4.ineffective: Demonstrate low levels of knowledge or commercial understanding, and lose respect from suppliers or other commercial counterparts

level4.effective: Question and challenge the value being delivered through commercial arrangements with delivery partners
level4.ineffective: Overlook or ignore the detail or shortcomings in contract delivery

level4.effective: Motivate improved performance by suppliers, challenge any gaps between contractual commitments and actual delivery through joint working with commercial/procurement experts
level4.ineffective: Take it for granted that suppliers are delivering what is needed

level5.effective: Identify and implement different ways of working deployed in other sectors e.g. using resources, assets and commercial arrangements
level5.ineffective: Overlook opportunities for collaboration with commercial partners to deliver more sustainable outcomes

level5.effective: Promote a strong focus on the needs of customers, suppliers and other delivery partners to develop new commercial models for the delivery of policy and business goals
level5.ineffective: Define success too narrowly and focus mostly on own concerns, ignoring opportunities to form commercial alliances which could support delivery

level5.effective: Manage strategic commercial relationships and delivery arrangements actively and effectively to provide ongoing value for money to the tax payer
level5.ineffective: Show limited active management of commercial arrangements associated with delivery of policy and business outcomes

level5.effective: Develop and apply market and economic understanding and insights, working with commercial experts, to support sound commercial decision-making and recommendations
level5.ineffective: Rarely approach or see limited value in working proactively with commercial experts to support commercial activities

level5.effective: Take a wide view, successfully achieving common goals with organisations that have different priorities
level5.ineffective: Do little to manage the strategic commercial relationship with delivery partners resulting in little or no longer term information sharing or planning

level5.effective: Ensure teams appreciate how market demands, investment decisions and other commercial considerations such as funding and pricing models influence suppliers and the delivery of services
level5.ineffective: Allow teams to be unaware of important commercial considerations for suppliers and other delivery partners

level6.effective: Role model strong leadership, influence and accountability for the achievement of commercial outcomes relevant to organisational goals
level6.ineffective: Show little evidence of leadership and accountability for delivering commercial outcomes

level6.effective: Draw on insights about the current and future dynamics in the economy to seize opportunities to stimulate economic growth
level6.ineffective: Pay little regard to social needs or protecting and enhancing the resources required to sustain economic growth

level6.effective: Seek out and facilitate the introduction of innovative business models, systems and approaches to deliver greater commerciality and sustainability
level6.ineffective: Allow ineffective business models or systems to continue, leading to a clear waste of money or resource

level6.effective: Commission strategic commercial relationships with delivery partners using strong influencing skills
level6.ineffective: Pay little attention to the delivery of outcomes and benefits from strategic commercial relationships

level6.effective: Ensure that all staff have appropriate levels of commercial awareness while creating and embedding an organisational culture that supports this
level6.ineffective: Do little to ensure that staff are equipped to consider commercial issues in shaping and developing policy and/or operational services

level6.effective: Ensure that commercial considerations and risks are fully considered in policy and implementation decision making, formation and delivery
level6.ineffective: Show little evidence of commercial understanding when shaping policies with senior stakeholders

achieving-commercial-outcomes.title: Achieving Commercial Outcomes

delivering-at-pace.description: Effectiveness in this area means focusing on delivering timely performance with energy and taking responsibility and accountability for quality outcomes. For all staff, it's about working to agreed goals and activities and dealing with challenges in a responsive and constructive way. At senior levels, it is about building a performance culture to deliver outcomes with a firm focus on prioritisation and addressing performance issues resolutely, fairly and promptly. It is also about leaders providing the focus and energy to drive activities forward through others and encourage staff to perform effectively during challenging and changing times.

level1.effective: Work in an organised manner using own knowledge and expertise to deliver on time and to standard
level1.ineffective: Show little interest in own work or in getting the job done properly

level1.effective: Work with energy and pace to get the job done
level1.ineffective: Wait to be told what to do and rely on others to sort out problems

level1.effective: Take responsibility for the quality of own work and keep manager informed of how the work is progressing
level1.ineffective: Ignore own part in ensuring their team can deliver and avoid supporting colleagues to get the job done even when the need is clear

level1.effective: Remain focused on delivery
level1.ineffective: Be easily discouraged or distracted

level1.effective: Maintain consistent performance
level1.ineffective: Give up quickly when things do not go smoothly

level1.effective: Participate in quality assurance of products or services
level1.ineffective: Miss the opportunity to suggest improvements through quality assurance

level2.effective: Create regular reviews of what and who is required to make a project/activity successful and make ongoing improvements
level2.ineffective: Fail to maintain pace and progress

level2.effective: Be interested and positive about what they and the team are trying to achieve
level2.ineffective: Display limited interest or positivity for their role or purpose

level2.effective: Take ownership of problems in their own area of responsibility
level2.ineffective: Avoid responsibility for dealing with problems

level2.effective: Remain positive and focused on achieving outcomes despite setbacks
level2.ineffective: Fail to adjust or react negatively when things change or go wrong

level2.effective: Check own and team performance against outcomes, make improvement suggestions or take corrective action when problems are identified
level2.ineffective: Neglect performance reviews and so be unable to give timely and constructive feedback

level2.effective: Set and achieve challenging goals and monitor quality
level2.ineffective: Blame others for poor quality work

level3.effective: Successfully manage, support and stretch self and team to deliver agreed goals and objectives
level3.ineffective: Give people work to do without supporting them to develop the skills and knowledge they need for the job

level3.effective: Show a positive approach in keeping their own and the team's efforts focused on the goals that really matter
level3.ineffective: Allow work flow to lose momentum or drift away from priorities

level3.effective: Take responsibility for delivering expected outcomes on time and to standard, giving credit to teams and individuals as appropriate
level3.ineffective: Give little or no support to others in managing poor performance, allow others' problems and obstacles to hamper progress

level3.effective: Plan ahead but reassess workloads and priorities if situations change or people are facing conflicting demands
level3.ineffective: Show no consideration for diversity-related needs of the team when organising the workload

level3.effective: Regularly monitor own and team's work against milestones or targets and act promptly to keep work on track and maintain performance
level3.ineffective: Allow poor performance to go unchallenged, causing workload issues for other team members

level3.effective: Coach and support others to set and achieve challenging goals for themselves
level3.ineffective: Allow organisational and other obstacles, including a lack of support, to stand in the way of own and others' aspirations

level4.effective: Get the best out of people by giving enthusiastic and encouraging messages about priorities, objectives and expectations
level4.ineffective: Lose focus, giving a confusing sense of what is important

level4.effective: Clarify business priorities, roles and responsibilities and secure individual and team ownership
level4.ineffective: Take the credit for delivery of outcomes without acknowledging the contribution of their teams

level4.effective: Adopt clear processes and standards for managing performance at all levels
level4.ineffective: Fail to set standards for timeliness and quality of monitoring in their own area of responsibility

level4.effective: Act as a role model in supporting and energising teams to build confidence in their ability to deliver outcomes
level4.ineffective: Overly focus on task delivery at expense of motivating and building capability to perform

level4.effective: Maintain effective performance in difficult and challenging circumstances, encouraging others to do the same
level4.ineffective: Fail to take a constructive approach to adversity, resorting quickly to blaming others for shortcomings

level4.effective: Review, challenge and adjust performance levels to ensure quality outcomes are delivered on time, rewarding success
level4.ineffective: Allow performance to drop without challenging quickly and responsively - continually focus on the negatives

level5.effective: Translate strategic priorities into clear outcome-focused objectives for managers and provide the energy and drive in achievement of these objectives
level5.ineffective: Set unrealistic, vague or uninspiring goals and lack clarity around expected outcomes

level5.effective: Take ownership of delivery against outcomes and give credit for others' delivery
level5.ineffective: Present delivery as someone else's issue

level5.effective: Maintain a strong focus on priorities, holding others to account for priorities and swiftly respond to changing requirements
level5.ineffective: Constantly revisit and revise priorities

level5.effective: Drive a performance culture within own area and support and encourage a focus on performance and priorities
level5.ineffective: Give limited personal support for delivery and allow the focus to drift away from critical priorities

level5.effective: Act as a role model for delivery by injecting enthusiasm and energy to achieve results
level5.ineffective: Put an overly strong focus on achieving tasks without efforts to motivate and energise people to perform

level5.effective: Promote resilience and responsiveness in the organisation by being open and honest about challenges, and the actions required to address unexpected developments
level5.ineffective: Overlook the impact of challenges and the impact on team and organisational resilience

level6.effective: Set, maintain and ensure a clear direction for the Department, with highly focused priorities and project outcomes
level6.ineffective: Display imprecision and lack of purpose about direction and focus of the Department

level6.effective: Retain accountability for achieving strategic priorities and outcomes
level6.ineffective: Allow the Department's focus to drift away from critical priorities and do not measure performance against them

level6.effective: Swiftly re-focus the Department on new priorities as changing situations dictate
level6.ineffective: Stick to strategy even when it is superseded by events which necessitate a change

level6.effective: Drive a performance culture across the Department and achieve results through others, resolutely holding them accountable for outcomes
level6.ineffective: Allow the Department to get away with poor results and inaction

level6.effective: Encourage, support and coach individuals and teams across the Department to energise delivery
level6.ineffective: Expect people to perform with enthusiasm without giving support and encouragement

level6.effective: Enable the organisation to remain focussed on core priorities irrespective of external challenges
level6.ineffective: Readily allow problems or external challenges to distract the Department from its core priorities

delivering-at-pace.title: Delivering at Pace

delivering-value-for-money.description: Delivering value for money involves the efficient, effective and economic use of taxpayers' money in the delivery of public services. For all staff, it means seeking out and implementing solutions which achieve the best mix of quality and effectiveness for the least outlay. People who do this well base their decisions on evidenced information and follow agreed processes and policies, challenging these appropriately where they appear to prevent good value for money. At senior levels, effective people embed a culture of value for money within their area/function. They work collaboratively across boundaries to ensure that the Civil Service maximises its strategic outcomes within the resources available.

level1.effective: Challenge others appropriately where they see wastage
level1.ineffective: Be careless or wasteful with resources or see where resources are being wasted but not raise this with team or manager

level1.effective: Be careful with all types of resource (e.g. money, time, materials, fuel, energy) that they use
level1.ineffective: Frequently choose convenience over cost effectiveness

level1.effective: Keep track of spend and make sure work is approved and signed off as necessary
level1.ineffective: Not follow appropriate control or authorisation processes for work, services or resource use

level1.effective: Handle numbers confidently, collate information ensuring accuracy of financial and performance data
level1.ineffective: Produce inaccurate financial and performance data with errors or omissions

level1.effective: Maintain recognised financial procedures and practices
level1.ineffective: Cut corners and not keep accurate financial records

level2.effective: Manage information and financial data so that it is accurate, easily located and reusable
level2.ineffective: Ignore financial management information procedures

level2.effective: Can account for expenditure and create well supported argument for extra expenditure e.g. overtime
level2.ineffective: Misunderstand basic financial concepts

level2.effective: Take opportunities to challenge misuse of resources in order to achieve value for money and sustainable ways of working
level2.ineffective: Favour the easiest method even if it is not the most cost effective – struggle to identify value for money opportunities

level2.effective: Understand that all actions have a cost and choose the most effective way to do something in a resource efficient way
level2.ineffective: Avoid using recommended tools and allow their team to do likewise

level2.effective: Ensure that recognised control procedures and practices are maintained
level2.ineffective: Use control and governance procedures and practices inappropriately or irregularly and allow their teams to do the same

level2.effective: Monitor resources against plans and budget, identify and flag up variances
level2.ineffective: Not manage resources against plan

level3.effective: Recommend actions to achieve value for money and efficiency
level3.ineffective: Ignore financial experts – not ask for advice or seek advice at the right time

level3.effective: Cultivate and encourage an awareness of cost, using clear simple examples of benefits and how to measure outcomes
level3.ineffective: Reserve resources for own team without considering wider business priorities or the organisation's financial environment

level3.effective: Work confidently with performance management and financial data to prepare forecasts and manage and monitor budget against agreed plans
level3.ineffective: Misinterpret or over-estimate performance and financial data used to forecast and monitor budgets and plans

level3.effective: Follow appropriate financial procedures to monitor contracts to ensure deliverables are achieved
level3.ineffective: Ignore the organisation's financial procedures or break rules for the sake of expediency

level3.effective: Monitor the use of resources in line with organisational procedures and plans and hold team to account
level3.ineffective: Be unable to justify own and their teams' use of resources

level4.effective: Understand impacts of financial position in own area and that of the organisation and use insight to curtail or support business and investment activities
level4.ineffective: Overlook the impact of decisions on the whole organisation and make recommendations without awareness of the wider financial position

level4.effective: Achieve the best return on investment and deliver more for less on specific budgets by managing resources and maximising the use of assets
level4.ineffective: Deliberately spend money up to the level of the available budget, ignoring the effectiveness of committing the expenditure

level4.effective: Balance policy aspiration and delivery, outline risk and benefits of different options to achieve value for money ensuring all submissions contain appropriate financial information
level4.ineffective: Be overly focused on minimising expenditure rather than ensuring it is well spent and will provide lasting added value

level4.effective: Weigh up priority and benefits of different actions and activities to consider how to achieve cost effective outcomes
level4.ineffective: Omit financial information from decision making and business planning

level4.effective: Work with financial processes and tools to evaluate options and ensure financial and management information are accurately reflected in business plans
level4.ineffective: Present business plans and cases that are not supported by robust or accurate financial and management information

level5.effective: Understand the financial position of own area, the organisation and the wider economy and recognise impacts of this when delivering services
level5.ineffective: Overlook opportunities to gather and make use of financial information in development of policy and plans

level5.effective: Make and encourage strategic choices on spend, challenge high risk costly projects and forgo non-priority expenditure
level5.ineffective: Take narrow view that low cost equates to good value

level5.effective: Promote and visibly demonstrate a culture of value for money in own area/function in order to focus managers on getting a good return for taxpayers' money
level5.ineffective: Adopt a short-term, incremental view of resource thus compromising sustainability of resource savings

level5.effective: Interpret a wide range of financial and management information and use financial data effectively in decisions
level5.ineffective: Rarely use financial or management information to support analysis and decision making

level5.effective: Develop robust business cases, with fully costed options identifying clear policy advantages and/or returns on investment to assist decision making
level5.ineffective: Recommend investment or cost not justified by the likely return

level5.effective: Understand and manage the risks and cost-drivers for own areas of responsibility in the context of strategic priority
level5.ineffective: Take a narrow approach to costs and cost-drivers

level6.effective: Drive and deliver a culture that emphasises continuous improvement, efficiency and value for money
level6.ineffective: Sign off spending with insufficient challenge or scrutiny

level6.effective: Maintain a clear focus on maximising resource efficiency, continually questioning the value of activities against strategic priorities
level6.ineffective: Allow non-core activities to divert funds and make decisions not in the best long-term financial interest of the Department

level6.effective: Be fluent at interpreting a wide range of financial and performance information and use this to determine policy and strategy delivery
level6.ineffective: Develop policy or strategy with insufficient exploration and consideration of financial or management information

level6.effective: Maintain good financial and budgetary discipline by ensuring accountability for financial controls and systems
level6.ineffective: Fail to deliver outcomes or strategy by significantly under or over-spending against agreed plans

level6.effective: Demonstrate transparency both in terms of decisions made around financial choices and money spent
level6.ineffective: Fail to demonstrate a full consideration of the financial aspects of a business decision and ignore the need for transparency and audit

delivering-value-for-money.title: Delivering Value for Money

managing-a-quality-service.description: Effectiveness in this area is about being organised to deliver service objectives and striving to improve the quality of service, taking account of diverse customer needs and requirements. People who are effective plan, organise and manage their time and activities to deliver a high quality and efficient service, applying programme and project management approaches to support service delivery. At senior levels, it is about creating an environment to deliver operational excellence and creating the most appropriate and cost effective delivery models for public services.

level1.effective: Communicate in a way that meets and anticipates the customer's requirements and gives a favourable impression of the Civil Service
level1.ineffective: Communicate with customers in a negative or unprepared way

level1.effective: Actively seek information from customers to understand their needs and expectations
level1.ineffective: Act without thinking through the necessary steps and disregard the customer's circumstances

level1.effective: Act to prevent problems, reporting issues where necessary
level1.ineffective: Allow service levels to drop or problems to occur before reporting

level1.effective: Gain the knowledge needed to follow the relevant legislation, policies, procedures and rules that apply to the job
level1.ineffective: Miss opportunities to learn or find out about relevant guidance and rules

level1.effective: Encourage customers to access relevant information or support that will help them understand and use services more effectively
level1.ineffective: Keep customers in the dark about relevant and useful information or partners

level1.effective: Take ownership of issues, focus on providing the right solution and keep customers and delivery partners up to date with progress
level1.ineffective: Treat people unfairly or make unrealistic commitments

level2.effective: Explain clearly to customers what can be done
level2.ineffective: Give customers and delivery partners an unrealistic picture of what is possible or focus on what cannot be done

level2.effective: Work with team to set priorities, create clear plans and manage all work to meet the needs of the customer and the business
level2.ineffective: Always rely on others to focus and plan their work

level2.effective: Ensure that levels of service are maintained – flag up risks or concerns in order to meet customer requirements
level2.ineffective: Focus on immediate service delivery problems and neglect overall quality or customer/end user needs

level2.effective: Keep internal teams, customers and delivery partners fully informed of plans and possibilities
level2.ineffective: Provide infrequent, unclear, insufficient updates to others in need of the information

level2.effective: Promote adherence to relevant policies, procedures, regulations and legislation, including equality and diversity and health and safety
level2.ineffective: Pay little attention to highlighting and explaining the reasons for compliance

level2.effective: Identify common problems or weaknesses in policy or procedures that affect service and escalate these
level2.ineffective: Show a lack of desire to improve the quality of service

level3.effective: Make effective use of project management skills and techniques to deliver outcomes, including identifying risks and mitigating actions
level3.ineffective: Has minimal understanding of what could go wrong or needs to be resolved as a priority

level3.effective: Develop, implement, maintain and review systems and service standards to provide quality, efficiency and value for money
level3.ineffective: Focus on delivering the task to the exclusion of meeting customer/end user requirements and needs

level3.effective: Work with team to set priorities, goals, objectives and timescales
level3.ineffective: Allocate or delegate work without clarifying deadlines or priorities

level3.effective: Establish mechanisms to seek out and respond to feedback from customers about service provided
level3.ineffective: Be unable to explain common customer problems or needs and how these are evolving

level3.effective: Promote a culture that tackles fraud and deception, keeping others informed of outcomes
level3.ineffective: Not give sufficient priority and attention to ensuring that fraud and deception is being tackled

level3.effective: Develop proposals to improve the quality of service with involvement from a diverse range of staff, stakeholders or delivery partners
level3.ineffective: Generate limited proposals to create service improvements and do so with little involvement of staff

level4.effective: Exemplify positive customer service behaviours and promote a culture focused on ensuring customer needs are met
level4.ineffective: Take little action when customer needs are not being met

level4.effective: Establish how the business area compares to customer service expectations and industry best practice and identify necessary improvements in plans
level4.ineffective: Ignore external trends that impact on the business area

level4.effective: Make clear, pragmatic and manageable plans for service delivery using programme and project management disciplines
level4.ineffective: Allow programmes or service delivery to lose momentum and focus and have no contingencies in place

level4.effective: Create regular opportunities for staff and customers to help improve service quality and demonstrate a visible involvement
level4.ineffective: Make changes to service delivery with minimal involvement from others

level4.effective: Ensure the service offer thoroughly considers customers' needs and a broad range of available methods to meet this, including new technology where relevant
level4.ineffective: Maintain a limited or out-dated view of how to respond to customers' needs

level4.effective: Ensure adherence to legal and regulatory requirements in service delivery and build diversity and equality considerations into plans
level4.ineffective: Disregard non–compliance with policies, rules and legal requirements and allow unfair or discriminatory practices

level5.effective: Facilitate flexible use of resources across grades through innovative structuring of teams and resources within own area
level5.ineffective: Maintain status quo in organisational structures and lack a flexible approach to manage resources and services

level5.effective: Clarify and articulate the diverse requirements of customers and delivery partners to support effective delivery
level5.ineffective: Spend limited time on seeking out and clarifying customer requirements of the Department

level5.effective: Use customer insight to determine and drive customer service outcomes and quality throughout own area
level5.ineffective: Not involve delivery partners sufficiently in delivering quality and customer service outcomes

level5.effective: Translate complex aims into clear and manageable plans and determine resource requirements to support implementation
level5.ineffective: Be unclear about overall service deliverables and resources required for implementation

level5.effective: Maintain and improve service by managing risks to ensure own area and partners deliver against defined outcomes
level5.ineffective: Establish unrealistic or confusing priorities and plans, leading to inefficiency in service/overlaps between activities

level5.effective: Work collaboratively with customers or service delivery partners to manage, monitor and deliver against service level agreements
level5.ineffective: Set service level agreements which cannot be delivered and fail to engage effectively or manage expectations with delivery partners

level6.effective: Ensure an in-depth and evolving understanding of the broad range of customer requirements is embedded in the Department
level6.ineffective: Allow the Department to operate with only superficial understanding of the customer/end user requirements

level6.effective: Determine and drive customer service outcomes at a broad strategic level and work across Government to deliver best quality service to customers
level6.ineffective: Give little attention to defining the customer requirement in setting strategic priorities

level6.effective: Ensure all parts of the delivery chain fully understand the required outcomes for the customer and articulate the impact of poor service on the Department's reputation to all involved
level6.ineffective: Give insufficient clarity around customer needs to the delivery partners and lose sight of which partner is responsible for delivery

level6.effective: Create a culture of working with and through delivery partners to achieve outcomes, establish and negotiate service levels and deliverables
level6.ineffective: Not give sufficient attention to managing customer expectations and outcomes at the highest levels

level6.effective: Define and integrate clear structures, systems and resources required across the Department to promote efficient service delivery
level6.ineffective: Establish unrealistic or confusing priorities and strategies at the highest level, leading to inefficiencies in service delivery

managing-a-quality-service.title: Managing a Quality Service

changing-and-improving.description: People who are effective in this area are responsive, innovative and seek out opportunities to create effective change. For all staff, it's about being open to change, suggesting ideas for improvements to the way things are done, and working in „smarter', more focused ways. At senior levels, this is about creating and contributing to a culture of innovation and allowing people to consider and take managed risks. Doing this well means continuously seeking out ways to improve policy implementation and build a leaner, more flexible and responsive Civil Service. It also means making use of alternative delivery models including digital and shared service approaches wherever possible.

level1.effective: Review working practices and come up with ideas to improve the way things are done
level1.ineffective: Remain attached to outdated procedures and technologies

level1.effective: Learn new procedures, seek to exploit new technologies and help colleagues to do the same
level1.ineffective: Adopt new processes without reporting difficulties that occur

level1.effective: Co-operate with and be open to the possibilities of change and consider ways to implement and adapt to change in own work role
level1.ineffective: Constantly make negative comments about change – unwilling to consider how change could help in own role

level1.effective: Be constructive in raising issues with managers about implemented changes and the impact these are having on the service
level1.ineffective: Be resistant to listening to ideas or plans for change, showing little interest in the reasons for change and how they can adapt their behaviour to thrive in the new environment

level1.effective: Respond effectively to emergencies
level1.ineffective: Resistant to sudden changes to usual work routine

level2.effective: Understand and apply technology to achieve efficient and effective business and personal results
level2.ineffective: Avoid use of technology and stick to tried and tested means of delivering business objectives

level2.effective: Consider and suggest ideas for improvements, sharing this feedback with others in a constructive manner
level2.ineffective: Be reluctant to consider ways to improve services in own area, even when improvements are urgently required

level2.effective: Conduct regular reviews of what and who is required to make a project/activity successful and make on-going improvements
level2.ineffective: Stick rigidly to the original brief, not adapting support/input to changing needs

level2.effective: Put aside preconceptions and consider new ideas on their own merits
level2.ineffective: Avoid considering different approaches, accepting the established way of doing things

level2.effective: Help colleagues, customers and corporate partners to understand changes and why they have been introduced
level2.ineffective: Dismiss colleagues' concerns about change and miss opportunities to discuss with them what is behind their concerns

level2.effective: Identify, resolve or escalate the positive and negative effects that change may have on own role/team
level2.ineffective: Implement change in a thoughtless and unstructured way, having not considered the possible effects it may have on others

level3.effective: Find ways to improve systems and structures to deliver with more streamlined resources
level3.ineffective: Retain resource intensive systems and structures that are considered too difficult to change

level3.effective: Regularly review procedures or systems with teams to identify improvements and simplify processes and decision making
level3.ineffective: Repeat mistakes and overlook lessons learned from changes that have been less effective in the past

level3.effective: Be prepared to take managed risks, ensuring these are planned and their impact assessed
level3.ineffective: Have ideas that are unfocused and have little connection to the realities of the business or customer needs

level3.effective: Actively encourage ideas from a wide range of sources and stakeholders and use these to inform own thinking
level3.ineffective: Not listen to suggested changes and not give reasons as to why the suggestion is not feasible

level3.effective: Be willing to meet the challenges of difficult or complex changes, encouraging and supporting others to do the same
level3.ineffective: Resist changing own approach in response to the new demands - adopting a position of „always done things like this'

level3.effective: Prepare for and respond appropriately to the range of possible effects that change may have on own role/team
level3.ineffective: Take little responsibility for suggesting or progressing changes due to perceived lack of control of processes

level4.effective: Understand and identify the role of technology in public service delivery and policy implementation
level4.ineffective: Ignore developments in technology that could benefit public service delivery and policy implementation

level4.effective: Encourage a culture of innovation focused on adding value – give people space to think creatively
level4.ineffective: Take a narrow and risk averse approach to proposed new approaches by not taking or following up on ideas seriously

level4.effective: Effectively capture, utilise and share customer insight and views from a diverse range of stakeholders to ensure better policy and delivery
level4.ineffective: Fail to effectively capture, utilise and share customer insight appropriately in the development of policies and services

level4.effective: Spot warning signs of things going wrong and provide a decisive response to significant delivery challenges
level4.ineffective: Remain wedded to the course that they have set and unresponsive to the changing demands of the situation

level4.effective: Provide constructive challenge to senior management on change proposals which will affect own business area
level4.ineffective: Spend limited time on engaging experts and relevant individuals in developing and testing proposals, failing to pass on relevant staff feedback

level4.effective: Consider the cumulative impact on own business area of implementing change (culture, structure, service and morale)
level4.ineffective: Give limited time to acknowledging anxieties and overcoming cynicism

level5.effective: Seek and encourage ideas, improvements and measured risk taking within own area to deliver better approaches and services
level5.ineffective: Restrict changes to own portfolio – do not integrate or align with change in other areas

level5.effective: Encourage a culture of imaginative thinking, seek to expand mindsets and genuinely listen to ideas from employees and stakeholders
level5.ineffective: Create a punitive environment for risk taking and responsive decision making – show intolerance of mistakes

level5.effective: Identify step changes that quickly transform flexibility, responsiveness and quality of service
level5.ineffective: Allow own area to become outdated and out of step with evolving changes and wider service requirements

level5.effective: Challenge the status quo in own and related areas to achieve value-adding improvements and change
level5.ineffective: Contribute to a culture of inertia across own portfolio of activities by focusing managers on delivering things as they always have

level5.effective: Lead the transformation of services to users, moving to a digital approach whenever possible
level5.ineffective: Miss opportunities to use alternative delivery models

level5.effective: Create effective plans, systems and governance to manage change and respond promptly to critical events
level5.ineffective: Adopt an unsystematic approach to change management – cause confusion about priorities and timelines

level6.effective: Challenge bureaucratic decision making, resourcing structures and processes across the Department and Civil Service to create a lean, flat and effective organisation.
level6.ineffective: Create/tolerate bureaucracies and inefficient ways of working which hinder effectiveness

level6.effective: Seek out opportunities for innovation and have the courage to take risks and make step changes to how things are done
level6.ineffective: Argue to retain the status quo, support current approaches, activities and processes without challenge, avoiding innovations and risks

level6.effective: Rethink systems and partnership approaches to simplify the Department and Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Continue with ineffective systems and partnership approaches

level6.effective: Create a culture of flexibility and responsiveness, mobilising the Department to respond swiftly to changing priorities
level6.ineffective: Tolerate colleagues operating in rigid, bureaucratic ways

level6.effective: Challenge the status quo and accepted assumptions at the highest levels across the Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Support incremental improvements within isolated areas rather than any fundamental shifts in approach

level6.effective: Consider fully the impact of change on organisation culture, wider Government structures and economic growth
level6.ineffective: Adopt a piecemeal approach to change management, focusing on tasks at the expense of culture and morale

changing-and-improving.title: Changing and Improving

making-effective-decisions.description: Effectiveness in this area is about being objective; using sound judgement, evidence and knowledge to provide accurate, expert and professional advice. For all staff, it means showing clarity of thought, setting priorities, analysing and using evidence to evaluate options before arriving at well reasoned justifiable decisions. At senior levels, leaders will be creating evidence based strategies, evaluating options, impacts, risks and solutions. They will aim to maximise return while minimising risk and balancing social, political, financial, economic and environmental considerations to provide sustainable outcomes.

level1.effective: Make and record effective decisions following the appropriate decision making criteria, framework or guidance
level1.ineffective: Compromise the consistency and quality of decision making

level1.effective: Ask questions when unsure what to do
level1.ineffective: Fail to research or use relevant information or support to carry out tasks

level1.effective: Undertake appropriate analysis to support decisions or recommendations
level1.ineffective: Make decisions or recommendations without the evidence to back them up

level1.effective: Investigate and respond to gaps, errors and irregularities in information
level1.ineffective: Overlook anomalies in evidence presented

level1.effective: Speak up to clarify decisions and query these constructively
level1.ineffective: Miss opportunities to take part in constructive conversations about decisions made

level1.effective: Think through the implications of own decisions before confirming how to approach a problem/issue
level1.ineffective: Give limited consideration to the impact of their decisions

level2.effective: Demonstrate accountability and make unbiased decisions
level2.ineffective: Avoid making decisions that lie within own remit; continually push decisions up

level2.effective: Examine complex information and obtain further information to make accurate decisions
level2.ineffective: Miss important evidence or make hasty judgements

level2.effective: Speak with the relevant people in order to obtain the most accurate information and get advice when unsure of how to proceed
level2.ineffective: Encounter problems by failing to check issues and relevance of information before using it

level2.effective: Explain clearly, verbally and in writing, how a decision has been reached
level2.ineffective: Share decisions in a way that leads to frustration or additional work

level2.effective: Provide advice and feedback to support others to make accurate decisions
level2.ineffective: Provide limited or no assurance that the right decisions are being made in team/work area

level2.effective: Monitor the storage of critical data and customer information to support decision making and conduct regular reviews to ensure it is stored accurately, confidentially and responsibly
level2.ineffective: Take little care with data and information storage; allow inaccuracies and mishandling to occur

level3.effective: Make decisions when they are needed, even if they prove difficult or unpopular
level3.ineffective: Miss opportunities or deadlines by delaying decisions

level3.effective: Identify a range of relevant and credible information sources and recognise the need to collect new data when necessary from internal and external sources
level3.ineffective: Only use evidence sources that support arguments or are easily accessible

level3.effective: Recognise patterns and trends in a wide range of evidence/data and draw key conclusions
level3.ineffective: Come to conclusions that are not supported by evidence

level3.effective: Explore different options outlining costs, benefits, risks and potential responses to each
level3.ineffective: Give little consideration to the people and resources impacted by decisions

level3.effective: Recognise scope of own authority for decision making and empower team members to make decisions
level3.ineffective: Create confusion by omitting to inform relevant people of amendments or decisions causing delays in implementation

level3.effective: Invite challenge and where appropriate involve others in decision making to help build engagement and present robust recommendations
level3.ineffective: Consistently make decisions in isolation or with a select group

level4.effective: Push decision making to the right level within their teams, not allow unnecessary bureaucracy and structure to suppress innovation and delivery
level4.ineffective: Involve only those in their peer group or direct reporting line in decision making

level4.effective: Weigh up data from various sources, recognising when to bring in experts/researchers to add to available information
level4.ineffective: Underestimate the work required to consider all the evidence needed and do not involve experts sufficiently early

level4.effective: Analyse and evaluate pros and cons and identify risks in order to make decisions that take account of the wider context, including diversity and sustainability
level4.ineffective: Take decisions without regard for the context, organisation risk, alignment with wider agendas or impacts (economic, social and environmental)

level4.effective: Draw together and present reasonable conclusions from a wide range of incomplete and complex evidence and data – able to act or decide even when details are not clear
level4.ineffective: Get confused by complexity and ambiguity and consider only simple or straightforward evidence

level4.effective: Identify the main issues in complex problems, clarify understanding or stakeholder expectations, to seek best option
level4.ineffective: Rely too heavily on gut instinct and provide unclear, incoherent or illogical analysis of core issues

level4.effective: Make difficult decisions by pragmatically weighing the complexities involved against the need to act
level4.ineffective: Make expedient decisions that offer less resistance or risk to themselves rather than decisions that are best for the business

level5.effective: Interpret a wide range of political and national pressures and influences to develop strategies
level5.ineffective: Give limited consideration to long-term sustainability or diversity impacts when shaping strategies and plans

level5.effective: Weigh up competing views to generate ways forward which will meet organisational goals
level5.ineffective: Have to continually revisit decisions due to lack of or poor quality analysis and evidence

level5.effective: Ensure involvement and consultation where necessary and take decisive action when required
level5.ineffective: Fail to follow a broad consultation process when coming to key decisions

level5.effective: Articulate options and large-scale reputational risks and impacts, including economic, environmental, political and social, and recommend plans to manage and mitigate
level5.ineffective: Provide advice without full consideration of risk, scenarios and options

level5.effective: Take quick, confident decisions at a strategic level to move things forward
level5.ineffective: Constantly change decisions based on new opinions, information or challenge

level5.effective: Outline direction of travel, recommendations and decisions for their area, taking account of financial and implementation issues
level5.ineffective: Overlook key information relating to cost and implementation issues

level6.effective: Navigate and balance a range of political, national and international pressures to shape the Department's strategy and priorities
level6.ineffective: Omit consideration of sustainable long-term development in strategy and give limited consideration to social, environmental or economic factors in analysis

level6.effective: Swiftly analyse complex and ambiguous data to provide clarity of thinking to the Department
level6.ineffective: Lack confidence in making decisions when the situation is unclear and constantly call for more information

level6.effective: Involve the right stakeholders and partners in making recommendations or decisions early on and continue to engage them
level6.ineffective: Provide recommendations or decisions without full and proper consultation

level6.effective: Identify and evaluate risks and options and develop Department wide strategies to manage and mitigate
level6.ineffective: Provide advice without full evaluation of risk, scenarios and options

level6.effective: Make unpopular decisions and defend them at the highest level when required
level6.ineffective: Constantly change decisions based on new opinions, information or challenge

level6.effective: Give unbiased advice to Ministers based on robust analysis, not just what is welcomed
level6.ineffective: Opt to give advice which the Minister/stakeholder wants to hear and ignore contrary evidence

making-effective-decisions.title: Making Effective Decisions

seeing-the-bigger-picture.description: Seeing the big picture is about having an in-depth understanding and knowledge of how your role fits with and supports organisational objectives and the wider public needs.
