For all staff, it is about focusing your contribution on the activities which will meet Civil Service goals and deliver the greatest value. At senior levels, it is about scanning the political context and taking account of wider impacts to develop long term implementation strategies that maximise opportunities to add value to the citizen and support economic, sustainable growth.

level1.effective: Gather information from a range of relevant sources inside and outside their Department to inform own work
level1.ineffective: Take actions/decisions without regard to the bigger picture

level1.effective: Understand what is required of them in their role and how this contributes to team and Departmental priorities
level1.ineffective: Show little interest in the work of the Department, not appreciating they have a role in meeting priorities

level1.effective: Consider how their own job links with and impacts on colleagues and others in partner organisations
level1.ineffective: Work on own tasks in isolation showing little interest in the wider context and relevant developments outside their immediate area

level2.effective: Keep up to date with a broad set of issues relating to the work of the Department
level2.ineffective: Have a narrow view of their role, without understanding the Department's wider activities

level2.effective: Develop understanding of how own and team's work supports achievement of Departmental priorities and delivery to the citizen
level2.ineffective: Carry out own tasks without considering how their work impacts or interacts with other teams

level2.effective: Focus on the overall goal and intent of what they are trying to achieve, not just the task
level2.ineffective: Fail to identify occasions when professional judgement and personal initiative are called for in order to deliver business objectives

level2.effective: Take an active interest in expanding their knowledge of areas related to own role
level2.ineffective: Rely solely on the knowledge they have already established about their role

level3.effective: Be alert to emerging issues and trends which might impact or benefit own and team's work
level3.ineffective: Ignore changes in the external environment that have implications for Departmental policy and considerations

level3.effective: Develop an understanding of own area's strategy and how this contributes to Departmental priorities
level3.ineffective: Shows limited interest in or understanding of Departmental priorities and what they mean for activities in their area

level3.effective: Ensure own area/team activities are aligned to Departmental priorities
level3.ineffective: Be overly focused on team and individual activities without due regard for how they meet the demands of the Department as a whole

level3.effective: Actively seek out and share experience to develop understanding and knowledge of own work and of team's business area
level3.ineffective: Take actions which conflict with or mis-align to other activities

level3.effective: Seek to understand how the services, activities and strategies in the area work together to create value for the customer/end user
level3.ineffective: Commit to actions without consideration of the impact on the diverse needs of customers/end users – apply a „one size fits all' approach

level4.effective: Anticipate economic, social, political, environmental and technological developments to keep activity relevant and targeted
level4.ineffective: Demonstrate lack of knowledge and insight into wider issues, developments and impacts related to own business area

level4.effective: Identify implications of Departmental and political priorities and strategy on own area to ensure plans and activities reflect these
level4.ineffective: Operate within own area without sufficient regard to how it creates value and supports the delivery ofDepartmental goals

level4.effective: Create policies, plans and service provision to meet citizens' diverse needs based on an up-to-date knowledge of needs, issues and relevant good practice
level4.ineffective: Continue to apply outdated practices which are unable to meet the diverse needs of citizens

level4.effective: Ensures relevant issues relating to their activity/policy area are effectively fed into strategy and big picture considerations
level4.ineffective: Miss opportunities to ensure important issues are considered by senior staff, raises small details as big picture issues

level4.effective: Adopt a Government-wide perspective to ensure alignment of activity and policy
level4.ineffective: Only consider the context of own business area and not those of others or of the organisation as a whole

level4.effective: Bring together views and perspectives of stakeholders to gain a wider picture of the landscape surrounding activities and policies
level4.ineffective: Lack clarity of or interest in gaining wider stakeholder perspectives

level5.effective: Anticipate and predict the long term impact of national and international developments, including economic, political, environmental, social and technological, on own area
level5.ineffective: Have limited insight into the changes and developments surrounding own area

level5.effective: Identify and shape how own area fits within and supports the work of the Department
level5.ineffective: Give limited attention to the bigger issues and interactions across departments and outside the Civil Service when defining strategy

level5.effective: Develop an in-depth insight into customers, citizens, services, communities and markets affected by their area and the wider public sector context
level5.ineffective: Lack insight into the wider context for own area – take a simplistic perspective on the issues and concerns of stakeholders

level5.effective: Create joined up strategies and plans that have positive impact and add value for stakeholders, citizens and communities
level5.ineffective: Develop strategies and plans with limited reference to the impact and value they will bring to the key stakeholders and to citizens now and in the future

level5.effective: Shape strategies and plans which help put into practice and support the Department's vision and long-term direction, including those shared with other departments
level5.ineffective: Maintain a narrow perspective – allow own area to become out of step or work against the overall objectives of the Department

level6.effective: Develop an in-depth insight into the dynamics and issues surrounding the Department and Government, including political, economic, social, environmental and technologicalimpacts
level6.ineffective: Focus on short term concerns, neglect long-term thinking about evolving and future issues and considerations for the Civil Service and Department

level6.effective: Clarify and shape the Department's role and purpose in delivering Civil Service priorities for the public and economic good
level6.ineffective: Show limited insight into Government expectations of the Department in generating value and growth in the UK

level6.effective: Understand where the Department sits within and aligns across the Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Focus on own immediate area of concern and not see interconnections across Civil Service

level6.effective: Articulate the Department's business model and help people see their role within it
level6.ineffective: Lack clarity about own role and that of staff in delivering the work of the Department

level6.effective: Create clear long-term strategies focused on adding value to the citizen and making real, lasting change beyond the Civil Service
level6.ineffective: Focus primarily on continuing historical activities based on short term priorities not linked to clear value and delivery for the citizen and the economy

level6.effective: Fully engage with and utilise Non Executive Directors wider experience and knowledge to support strategic decision making
level6.ineffective: Operate independently, without reference to the wider system of knowledge and experience around them

seeing-the-bigger-picture.title: Seeing the Big Picture

description:
About this framework
====================

We are introducing a new competency framework to support the Civil Service Reform Plan and the new
performance management system. The competency framework sets out how we want people in the Civil Service to
work. It puts the Civil Service values of honesty, integrity, impartiality and objectivity at the heart of everything we
do and it aligns to the three high level leadership behaviours that every civil servant needs to model: Set Direction;
Engage People and Deliver Results. Civil servants work in a huge range of jobs across the country and overseas
but one thing we have in common is that we are here to support the elected Government, providing advice to help
shape its policies and ensuring seamless and practical implementation in line with those policies.

Competencies are the skills, knowledge and behaviours that lead to successful performance. The framework
outlines 10 competencies, which are grouped into 3 clusters as set out above. For each competency there is a
description of what it means in practice and some examples of effective and ineffective behaviours at all levels.
The competencies are intended to be discrete and cumulative, with each level building on the levels below i.e. a
person demonstrating a competency at level 3 should be demonstrating levels 1 and 2 as a matter of course.
These indicators of behaviour are not designed to be comprehensive, but provide a clear sense of and greater
understanding and consistency about what is expected from individuals in the Civil Service.

## What does it mean for me?

The framework will be used for recruitment, performance management and development discussions and for
decisions about progression. Some Departments introduced it in April 2012 with the rest of Government doing so
from April 2013. In these new arrangements your business objectives will set out “what” you need to achieve over
the year and this competency framework will set out “how” you need to work to achieve those objectives.

Most of you will need to focus on a number of competencies, usually around six, identified with your manager as
being essential to your role. You are encouraged to discuss the framework with your line manager to identify the
competencies that apply most to your job role.

This framework has been developed in partnership with Civil Service professions. If you work as part of a
profession with a separate framework this will complement your professional framework and should be used
alongside it.

The framework is made up of ten competencies. Below is a list of all the competencies with a high-level summary
of each one.
